Del Potro defeated the Swiss player with a score of 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3. Del Potro, ranked 165th, is returning to Grand Slam tennis after missing over two years due to injury. He will next face either Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro expressed his happiness at returning to tennis after a long absence. In other matches, Kyrgios defeated Brown in a five-set match and will face Lopez in the third round. Lopez had also come back from two sets down to defeat Fognini. Berdych and Tsonga had routine victories in their matches.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations (AfCON) after complaining about the organization of the 2015 AfCON, where they were controversially defeated by Equatorial Guinea due to a disputed penalty. They apologized to Caf to avoid disqualification. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 AfCON qualifiers for refusing to host the 2015 AfCON due to Ebola concerns but had the ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), reducing their fine significantly. Both Tunisia and Morocco have since resolved their issues with Caf, allowing them to participate in the 2017 AfCON. Tunisia, aiming for their first AfCON title since 2004, will compete in Group A, while Morocco will be in Group F. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 AfCON would mark their 13th consecutive appearance, a record.

McLaren, a historically successful Formula 1 team with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a decline. The team's recent struggles began in 2013 due to poor chassis design, and despite recent improvements in the car, issues with the Honda power unit persist. McLaren's golden era was in the 1980s with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and later with Mika Hakkinen in the late 1990s. The team faced scandals, including a $100 million fine in 2007 for illegal possession of Ferrari technical data and another in 2009 dubbed 'lie-gate.' Despite past successes and a cycle of triumph and decline, McLaren is currently in a period of struggle, though team principal Ron Dennis believes success will return, particularly with Fernando Alonso's return and the potential of the Honda partnership.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven after a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, 43, the license holder, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The court was told the bar did not strictly follow licensing laws and operated improperly into the morning. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, fined O'Neill £3,000, and Thomas £1,000, noting O'Neill had an "appalling record" and the case was among the worst he had encountered.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season with eight made in the game, helping the Golden State Warriors defeat the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Curry scored 45 points and added nine assists, while Klay Thompson contributed 26 points. The Warriors avoided their first three-game losing streak this season. Meanwhile, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, overcoming a 19-point halftime deficit. Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds, and Derrick Rose scored 12 points for the Bulls, who moved into third place in the Eastern Conference. The Heat were outscored 57-27 after halftime, with Hassan Whiteside scoring 19 points and 16 rebounds and Dwyane Wade shooting just 4 for 20.

A YouTube star named Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic during a meeting at Melwood. Initially believed to be a regular fan, van Velzen demonstrated his free-kick skills, impressing the players with his dead-ball abilities. The experience was described as amazing by van Velzen, who also revealed Balotelli's infamous slogan from a past match.

The passage discusses the benefits of oophorectomy (ovary removal) for women with BRCA1 gene mutations who have been diagnosed with breast cancer. It highlights that removing the ovaries can reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60% in BRCA1 carriers, based on a study analyzing 676 patients. The procedure was particularly effective when done within two years of diagnosis, with a 73% reduction in death. However, this benefit was not observed in BRCA2 carriers. The study also noted a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. Angelina Jolie, a BRCA1 carrier, had a double mastectomy and later an oophorectomy to reduce her cancer risks. The findings suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer. Genetic testing is available for BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, and PTEN mutations, with BRCA mutations being more common in Ashkenazi Jewish women. The passage also mentions that estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer patients benefit more from oophorectomy.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were killed when an Amtrak train hit them on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred shortly before 10 am when the train, heading from Charlotte to New York City, struck them on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. Both were pronounced dead at the scene. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes, though none of the 166 passengers were injured, except for a man who fell ill and received treatment. A man who met the couple said they may have been homeless and were struggling to cross the railroad tracks with a grocery cart. The train eventually continued its route after the delay.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, became an undercover DEA informant in the 1980s after fleeing Colombia due to a confrontation with his boss. He provided information that helped the DEA take down key figures such as Carlos Lehder Rivas and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Toro worked for the DEA for 27 years as a valuable asset, assisting in undercover operations globally, but was never paid and was promised U.S. citizenship. After retiring due to health issues, he is now facing deportation because the DEA did not fulfill its promise of citizenship, leaving him in legal limbo without a green card or passport. Toro fears being sent back to Colombia, where he believes he would be killed, and is seeking help from former colleagues and advocates to secure his future in the U.S.

The U.S. body regulating internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new ".sucks" domain name to charge high fees from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies trying to protect their reputations. Celebrities and major brands, including YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo, have had their names registered on ".sucks" domains. Kevin Spacey is among those who reportedly paid to have their name removed from these domains. The company initially charged $2,499 a year for the domains, though resellers sold them for around $2,000 a year. ICANN has sent a letter to U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine if the company's actions are illegal. Industry groups have criticized the company's practices as a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory."

A baby boy's body was found in 1988 wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. The case remained unsolved for 27 years until police exhumed the body in 2015 as part of a case review. A DNA sample from the boy's leg bone was matched to a possible relative in the national police database, leading to the identification of the boy's mother, who was arrested on suspicion of infanticide. However, the charge was dropped after she revealed the baby was stillborn and she had concealed her pregnancy. The woman explained she had given birth in secret and placed the baby in the pond. The baby was originally buried anonymously, but a support group paid for a headstone naming him Peter after the church. A second post-mortem confirmed no foul play, and the baby was reburied in the churchyard on the 26th anniversary of his discovery. The case highlights the use of DNA advancements in solving cold cases and the emotional impact on all involved.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, unlawfully imprisoned a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, by driving him away from his destination in an attempt to teach him a lesson for allegedly trying to avoid paying the fare. During the drive, Hicks jumped out of the moving taxi at over 20mph, resulting in severe brain injuries, epilepsy, and a need for lifelong care. The High Court ruled that Young's actions were unlawful, entitling Hicks to damages. The compensation is expected to be about 50% of the family's requested amount, which was in the "hundreds of thousands of pounds" range. The judge acknowledged the severity of Hicks' injuries and the risks involved in Young's conduct, but reduced the damages by 50% due to Hicks' decision to jump from the moving vehicle. Hicks, now 27, requires round-the-clock care from his mother and is unable to work. Both parties have been given permission to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the final compensation amount.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens were activated in Kansas as multiple storms brought reports of tornadoes. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, less than 15 miles west of Wichita, and moved northeast, missing the city but posing risks to other communities. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned about the dangers of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Kansas was not the only affected area; a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. Residents shared photos of the damage, including fallen trees and flooded streets. In Leadington, unusual dark clouds were captured on Instagram, and in Farmington, hail as large as baseballs was reported. More storms are expected on Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight match in New Jersey. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot, and he believes he can dominate Machida by cutting him off and forcing him to fight his style. He feels confident in his mixed martial arts skills and believes Machida has few opportunities to win on the feet. Machida, on the other hand, is confident in his ability to upset Rockhold and earn a title shot, citing his preparation and strategy. Both fighters respect each other but are determined to win the fight.

A light general aviation aircraft landed without deploying its landing gear, resulting in a belly landing at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane skidded along the runway, causing damage to the propellers and scraping the tarmac. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, realized his mistake and re-engaged the engines, taking off again and flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The incident is being investigated by the FAA, and gear-up landings are commonly caused by human error or mechanical faults.

Summary: Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment with Yaya Toure's performance but pledged to support him until the end of the season. Sportsmail reported that City is considering offers for Toure as they aim to rejuvenate their squad. Despite criticism, Toure is determined not to be forced out, and Pellegrini emphasized his importance to the team. City's poor performance in the Premier League has led to questions about Pellegrini's future, but goalkeeper Joe Hart affirmed the manager's support. Additionally, West Ham's Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell against moving to Manchester City, citing the experiences of other players who struggled after joining the club.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," was set to be extradited to Italy to serve a seven-year sentence for his involvement with the Cosa Nostra. However, his case expired last October, and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. Rancadore has lived in the UK for over 20 years under the name Marc Skinner. Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished if more than double the time of the penalty has passed, which is the case here. Although the conviction remains, the sentence is no longer enforceable. Rancadore's solicitor is confident the Italian government will now withdraw the extradition request, allowing him to remain in the UK. Legal experts criticized the lengthy and costly extradition process, and the Crown Prosecution Service admitted to administrative errors that contributed to the delay. Rancadore's case will still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court, but he is expected to be discharged from the proceedings.

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. This race will be McCoy's last in a Grade One event, and his final day's rides will be confirmed on Friday. Interestingly, McCoy announced his retirement after winning with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. Other competitors in the race include Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and crime scene photos. After decades of avoiding them, Ritter finally viewed the photos last year and expressed regret for not seeing them earlier. She described the disturbing details of her daughter's condition, including her swollen face, vomit, and blood on her scalp. Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years before Barrett was arrested in 2006 due to DNA evidence linking him to the crime.

Rory McIlroy is determined to win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, a feat only achieved by a handful of players. He considers his 2011 Masters collapse as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons about himself and his game. McIlroy has only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, but he remains confident about his chances this year. He also mentions the importance of Augusta National as a sanctuary from external pressures. Despite challenges such as calling off his wedding and legal disputes, McIlroy has had great success in recent years, winning multiple major titles. He aims to win the Masters and potentially multiple times in the future.

The passage summarizes various trending stories from the week. These include the appearance of four rainbows in the New York area, captured by a fashion CEO, the trend of hiring exotic dancers for wakes in rural China, a celebrity interview that made RDJ agitated, the rise of the "Kylie Jenner Challenge" involving lip plumping, a 102-year-old woman going back in time with filmmakers, a controversial prom-posal referencing bombs, Ewan McGregor joining the cast of "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in "Black Mass," a creative pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombing his son. All these stories gained attention and trended online.

New figures reveal that 272 children in England were hospitalised last year due to disabilities caused by fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), which results from alcohol exposure in the womb. Experts suggest the actual number of affected children is likely higher. Research indicates that at least one in 100 babies in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, or physical issues due to prenatal alcohol exposure, equating to around 7,500 cases annually. FAS is a lifelong condition with no cure, and it is under-diagnosed. Niamh Brown, a 15-year-old with FAS, requires constant support and cannot live independently. The condition can also lead to other medical issues, including liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, vision loss, and epilepsy. The government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption to no more than two units twice a week, but some experts argue that complete abstinence is necessary during pregnancy.

A robber named Shaun Andrew Mckerry, known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" due to his habit of returning home after crimes, was jailed for six years after an attempted robbery at a post office in Shildon, County Durham. During the incident on March 15, Mckerry, armed with an axe, was tackled by the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, and hit with a baseball bat by his wife, Sam, which helped disarm him. The police later arrested Mckerry, who had a history of juvenile offenses and multiple convictions for crimes such as shoplifting, aggravated vehicle-taking, and burglary.

Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley, have been charged with gang rape after an alleged sexual assault at a Canadian naval base. They appeared in court in Nova Scotia and were granted bail with strict conditions, including staying in Nova Scotia, surrendering their passports, and living at the Stadacona naval base. They must also continue working for the Royal Navy and cannot resign without court permission. The alleged incident occurred on April 10 after the men returned from a hockey game. The victim, a young woman in her early 20s, was accompanied by a friend invited to the party by Canadian servicemen. The men are banned from contacting the victim and six witnesses and must return to court on May 27. They are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which could lead to up to 14 years in prison. The British High Commission has stated that the allegations are serious but remain only allegations at this stage.

A mother named Valerie Jackson from Las Vegas was shocked when a stranger reported her to the police for child abuse because her son, four-year-old RJ Jackson, has a rare skin condition called Netherton's syndrome, which causes his skin to appear red and scaly. Netherton's syndrome is a rare congenital skin disease, a more extreme form of ichthyosis, which makes the skin red and scaly and can cause hair, infection, and allergy problems. Valerie and her husband have to regularly cover RJ's body with creams to ease his symptoms, but they face taunts and misunderstandings from people who mistake his condition for abuse. RJ was diagnosed with the condition as a baby, and Valerie found information about the disease through a Facebook group. Despite the challenges, Valerie remains positive about her son and hopes that as RJ grows, people will become more aware of his condition.

Protein World's controversial advertising campaign, featuring a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield with the slogan "Are you beach body ready?" sparked significant backlash from feminists, body image campaigners, and the public. The posters, displayed on the London Underground, were criticized for promoting an unrealistic and unhealthy body image. A Change.org petition calling for the removal of the adverts garnered over 50,000 signatures, and the Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints. Several posters were defaced by bloggers and activists who opposed the message. Transport for London (TFL) confirmed the posters were being removed as they had reached the end of their three-week advertising period. Protein World defended the campaign, claiming the image was unphotoshopped and aimed to inspire healthier lifestyles, but faced criticism for being offensive and unrealistic. The controversy also included a protest in Hyde Park and online discussions, with some individuals defending the campaign while others condemned it as anxiety-inducing and sexist. Additionally, the company reported receiving threats, including a bomb threat, and stated they would not change their advertising methods in the future.

Rail firms are facing criticism for planning significant fare hikes, up to 87%, just ten days after the general election, despite promises from main political parties to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has asked First Great Western to review its decision to nearly double fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his constituency. The fare increase has angered Cameron's constituents, with passengers currently paying £33.30 for an off-peak return to London, which will rise to £62.40, an 87% increase. Train companies can increase unregulated fares three times a year, which make up about half of their revenue. First Great Western claims the change is to align the North Cotswolds route with other services and offers cheaper advanced single tickets. Other sharp price hikes include increases on various routes, with Virgin stating that most of its price hikes affect fares that are at least 20% cheaper than those of rival firms.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier and retired HGV driver, was blinded in one eye after being hit in the face with a brick thrown through his front door by unidentified attackers in Oldham. The incident occurred when he confronted the vandals, who had been throwing stones at his home. He and his new wife, Elaine, were in their living room writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts when the attack happened. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. The police are investigating the attack, which they believe may have been a case of youths "messing around," with no clear motive. The couple, who married just three weeks prior, now feel unsafe in their neighborhood and plan to move.

Tom Poynton, Derbyshire's wicketkeeper, has signed a new one-year contract extension after successfully returning from a leg injury sustained in a road accident that also claimed his father's life in April 2014. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season but made a comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's elite performance director, praised Poynton's resilience and expressed hope that the new contract will give him the confidence to perform well this summer.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. To cope with his treatment, he created a superhero mask inspired by the Ninja Turtles, which helped him feel stronger during radiotherapy. His bravery and unique approach to treatment gained global attention, leading to gifts from Nickelodeon and recognition from Cancer Research UK. After undergoing chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley was declared cancer-free. He will continue with regular check-ups to ensure his health. His parents are overjoyed, and he is expected to return to school full-time. Neuroblastoma is a cancer of specialized nerve cells, affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually, and treatment varies depending on the child's age, tumour size, and spread.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old player for Aston Villa, has been performing well and is now being considered by both the Republic of Ireland and England for international representation. Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa's manager, believes Grealish should focus on his club career before making a decision on his international future. Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish needs to continue impressing with Villa to make the right choice later. Grealish's father also supports this approach, stating that club football should come first. The decision is ultimately up to Grealish, and he may have the opportunity to play for both teams in a friendly match later in the season.

The passage discusses the high landing fees charged at airports for private jet travelers, highlighting that these fees can be surprisingly high at certain hubs, such as Salzburg in Austria and Darwin in Australia. It mentions that owning and traveling by private jet is a luxury for the wealthy, with a growing industry worth trillions of dollars in the US and Europe. The passage also lists some of the most expensive airports for landing fees, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive, followed by Narita International Airport and Kansai International Airport in Japan. Other notable airports include Bristol in the UK, Toronto Pearson in Canada, and La Guardia in New York. The text also references the high demand during events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix, with significant costs for private jet travel during these times.

A passage describes a video of Cooper, a Labrador dog, and his companion Daisy, who visit McDonald's for ice cream. While Daisy takes a few licks, Cooper eats the entire cone in one bite. Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, explains that Cooper eats quickly, so she ensures Daisy gets her share first. The video has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers find the scene cute, while others criticize Gallegos for feeding the dogs ice cream. Gallegos defends her actions, stating that Cooper is healthy and enjoys treats like ice cream and a Starbucks "pup-uccino," which is just whipped cream.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after a successful interim spell, signing a three-year deal. He initially joined the club as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer but took over as manager in February when Johnston left. Locke has only lost once in seven games since taking charge and will hold a press conference on Friday.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, is facing a challenge from her son's school, Seminole County Elementary, which has threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the use of essential oils. The oils, from the company Doterra, are used by Kemp to help Logan stay calm and focused. Teachers claim the oils are a distraction and have a strong smell that affects other students. Kemp argues that the oils are natural and beneficial for her son, questioning why they are considered problematic when other chemicals are allowed. Although the school board mentioned the oils caused a "problem," the Lake County School District stated they would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue." Kemp plans to continue using the oils and fighting the decision. The family uses scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire spread through 90 condos, causing the building to collapse. Smoke was visible from three miles away, and the blaze was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews were deployed but could not get inside the summer homes. The fire is under investigation, with claims suggesting it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The building manager, Rob Taber, and other residents lost everything in the fire. The complex is typically used as a holiday home between May and November.

The Queen, who is 88 years old, continues to enjoy riding her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, despite her age and a recent knee injury that has reduced her riding time. She prefers to ride without a helmet, using a silk scarf instead, and has never worn a riding helmet throughout her life. The Queen has a long-standing love for horses, beginning at age four with a Shetland pony named Peggy, and has bred various horses and ponies over the years, including fell ponies at Hampton Court. Fell ponies, an ancient breed from Cumbria, have been historically significant, used for trade, transport, and later as family riding ponies due to their gentle nature. The Queen remains an active and enthusiastic equestrienne, with her grandchildren also riding some of her ponies.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels turned fatal when Phillip Pama, 28, allegedly killed Leon Yeaman, 55, with a single punch during an argument. The incident occurred around 9 pm on Thursday night when Yeaman was making noise in his yard. Pama, a shift worker who was sleeping at the time, confronted Yeaman, leading to the altercation. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Yeaman was known for being loud and drunk, and that Pama acted in self-defense. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene, and Pama was charged with manslaughter. He was granted conditional bail and must adhere to restrictions, including a curfew and regular police check-ins. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

A jilted 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, wanted to hire a hitman to torture and murder 15-year-old Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship for a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) to a friend to find someone willing to carry out the attack. Police set up a sting operation, with an undercover officer posing as a hitman during a meeting with Simonova in Shatura, near Moscow. A hidden camera recorded Simonova describing in detail how she wanted the boy to be tortured, including breaking his arms and legs, damaging his kidneys, and making him suffer unbearable pain before she would "finish him." After she handed over some expenses money to the undercover officer, she was arrested by armed police in her car. Simonova now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief and hoped that Simonova would receive a life sentence.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, talks to God every day but never discusses football with his wife or God. He separates his professional and family life and has a strong faith in God, though he doesn't attend church regularly. Mourinho claims he is a good person, a good family man, and tries to support others. He has been involved with the World Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger. He also mentioned that he was fined £25,000 for claiming there was a campaign against Chelsea. Mourinho's son celebrates Chelsea's Capital One Cup victory with the players.

After an eight-year absence, Bob Barker, the former host of "The Price is Right," made a return appearance on the April 1 edition of the show. Barker, who had hosted the game show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, handled the first game, "Lucky Seven," and then handed over hosting duties to Drew Carey. At 91 years old, Barker appeared spry and did not seem to miss a beat despite his long absence from the show.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday morning for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was taken into custody by the Metropolitan Police on the 3200 block of D Street SE and charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin works in the Foreign Missions Branch, which deals with U.S. diplomatic activities. He is scheduled for arraignment but does not have an attorney listed. This incident follows another case involving a high-ranking supervisor who was also placed on leave for alleged misconduct, and it adds to ongoing investigations into misconduct within the Secret Service, including a previous incident involving two officials driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

A freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, named Atif Saeed, took a significant risk by getting within 10 feet of a hungry lion in a safari park to capture a photo. Armed only with a camera, he managed to take a few pictures before the lion became aware of his presence due to the camera's shutter sound, forcing him to retreat quickly to safety. Saeed described the encounter as a close call and admitted he wouldn't repeat the experience.

A woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn and later pronounced dead. She had no identification and a distinctive tattoo on her right leg, which appears to be the name "Monique" within a heart with a rose. The NYPD has released images of the tattoo in hopes of identifying her. The cause of death is pending a medical examiner's report, and authorities are asking for public assistance to identify the woman.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a self-sufficient home on the bed of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 and being unable to afford a traditional home. The project took about 18 months to complete and cost around $25,000. The home, made of wood and steel, is solar-powered, has two bedrooms, a loft, a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is located on a lot surrounded by nature. They source water from a nearby spring and use gas for heating and hot water. The couple is nearly self-sufficient and plans to build another similar home in the future.

A study found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class scored significantly higher in early literacy tests compared to those who didn't use iPads or used them individually. The research, conducted with 352 students, showed shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher. The study suggests that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just collaboration itself, contributed to the improved results. The findings suggest schools should reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation in China after learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "super pig," can balance on two legs and has captured the hearts of thousands since a video of it went online. The piglet lives with its siblings, who were born with all four legs, and villagers have been flocking to see it. The piglet's owner, Ms. Duan, discovered its unique condition when she noticed something strange during feeding. This is not the first animal in China to gain attention for walking on two legs; a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became a star attraction after learning to walk on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member named Todd Phillips was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car while exiting the pit box. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, suffered a leg injury and received stitches before being released. Dracone spun out on Turn One and did not finish the race, ending up in 23rd place. The race was affected by rain, which caused many cars to struggle with traction.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally killed his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. He confessed that his actions were driven by jealousy over men looking at her. Cicera, who was part of a dance group called Jaula das Gostozuedas, was also referred to as Amanda Bueno on stage. After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was arrested after crashing it. Police found weapons in his car, and he now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, the journalist and author of the best-selling book *I Quit Sugar*, has shared her personal struggle with mental illness, including anxiety and thyroid disease, which led her to feel her life was not worth living and even consider taking her own life. She described feeling isolated, without a partner or children, and unable to see a future. Wilson now acknowledges her anxiety and believes it is closely linked to depression. She emphasizes the importance of recognizing this connection to address the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. Wilson has since found some peace and encourages others to seek help if needed.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she attacked her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. The ex-girlfriend was found using heroin in Curtin's bathroom, and after she refused to leave, Curtin used the crowbar to strike her. Prosecutors later dropped the charges, citing that Curtin's actions were "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law permits the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave. Curtin's attorney claimed the ex-girlfriend had been harassing and threatening her for years, trying to bring her boyfriend back into drug use. Curtin gave birth in January 2015 and is now living with her parents, having moved on from the relationship. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed eating treats but reacted with disgust when her owner tried to trick her by adding broccoli. She spat the vegetable out on the floor, and the passage hopes the two children living with her don't follow her example. Gemma also enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website redirected visitors to a pornographic page. The issue occurred because the URL for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was shut down in 2011, was registered by a porn site. HSBC removed the hyperlink and denied any association with the external site, offering a public apology. The bank emphasized that its website remained secure and that its internet banking services were unaffected.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus, along with his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah, was trapped in a second-floor bedroom during a house fire in Clinton on Sunday morning. Marcus called 911 and provided clear instructions to the dispatcher, staying calm throughout the 11-minute call. He reassured his sister and guided rescuers to their location. Firefighters broke a window to enter the room and rescued the siblings, with Marcus being handed out the window by a firefighter who then gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both children were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped on their own and were also hospitalized.

Blue fluorescent algae have lit up Australia's east coast, with amazing pictures taken in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the neon glow as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the glow is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn, usually due to natural causes. The algae gives off light as a defense mechanism and preys on diatoms.

New tests can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors to determine their aggressiveness, helping some patients avoid chemotherapy. These tests, such as Endopredict, assess the risk of cancer recurrence, with some showing a risk as low as five percent. This can be as effective as or better than chemotherapy. While chemotherapy is commonly given after surgery to prevent recurrence, it has severe side effects and is often unnecessary for some patients. The tests are currently available privately at a cost of about £2,500, but there is hope they may soon be available on the NHS. Experts believe these tests help patients make informed decisions about their treatment, potentially saving costs by avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy. Becca Cornford, a breast cancer patient, opted out of chemotherapy after her test showed a low risk of recurrence, choosing instead regular monitoring.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with some ships like HMS Ocean having multiple cases. The pregnancies are believed to have occurred before deployment or during leave, as there is a strict "no touching" rule in place at sea. This issue has been highlighted in the context of Commander Sarah West, the first female captain of a Royal Navy warship, who was flown back to the UK following allegations of a relationship with a crew member. The data also shows that nearly 100 female soldiers were evacuated from Afghanistan and Iraq due to pregnancy, with strict military rules banning pregnant women from serving in war zones.

A drone containing radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's Prime Minister's residence, raising concerns about potential drone-related terrorism. The incident occurred on the same day a court approved the restart of two nuclear reactors in Kagoshima, a move opposed by many Japanese due to fears over nuclear energy. The drone had a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle with cesium, a substance linked to the Fukushima nuclear disaster. The amount of cesium found is not immediately harmful to humans, but the discovery has prompted concerns about the security risks of drones, especially ahead of the Olympics and G7 summit. Current Japanese law does not restrict drone flights around government buildings, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was not present at the time of the discovery.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from China, takes his 84-year-old mother who suffers from Alzheimer's to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He does this to ensure her safety, as she has a history of getting lost when left alone. He ties a sash around both of their waists to prevent her from falling off. His mother has her own room at his workplace, a bank, and he regularly checks on her. Lu feels a strong sense of duty to care for his mother, as she once cared for him and his siblings. The journey to work takes an hour, during which they chat to keep her calm and safe.

A major study reveals that heavy drinking and binge-drinking among Americans have increased significantly between 2005 and 2012, with women showing the most substantial rise. Heavy drinking is defined as consuming more than one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking is defined as consuming four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion. The study, conducted by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, found that the rate of binge drinking among women increased more than seven times that of men nationwide. The increase is attributed to shifting social norms, economic factors, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study also highlights regional variations in drinking rates, with some counties reporting much higher rates than others. The rise in binge drinking has led to increased alcohol-related deaths and costs, with experts noting the need for better public health interventions.

The passage highlights concerns that doctors in England are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting women and their babies at risk. It notes that over a quarter of women now have caesareans, with the rate doubling since the early 1990s. While caesareans can be medically necessary, the World Health Organization (WHO) warns that they are often performed without medical need, leading to complications, increased costs, and diverting resources from other patients. The WHO recommends a caesarean rate of 10-15%, whereas the NHS allows them for non-medical reasons, such as anxiety about childbirth. The procedure is more expensive than natural birth and can cause infections and other health issues.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. She was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, on April 17 and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Filkins claimed ownership of the house but fled when Conklin called the police. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket. Filkins was arrested later that day after trying to re-enter the home. Items missing include furniture, a Weber grill, lamps, and a painting. The police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them and are offering assistance with restitution. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with her after police posted humorous photos and messages on her Facebook page to locate her. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border after Bella lost it at a friend's birthday party. Police, realizing the phone was unlocked, used it to post selfies, puns, and photos of the phone in various locations, including a "holding cell," to notify Bella and amuse her friends. The police also humorously reassured her that the phone was safe and fully charged. Bella eventually reclaimed her phone without needing to provide her name, as officers recognized her from her Facebook page. She appreciated the police's good humor and has since added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippo was mauled to death when it got caught in a fight between two adult male hippos at Isimangaliso Wetland Park in South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface before dying hours later. Its mother watched in horror but had stayed with her herd, possibly believing it was safer. A tour operator witnessed the incident and described how the mother tried to rescue the calf but was unable to. The cause of the attack remains unclear, possibly due to play, jealousy, or intent to kill.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is being sold for £575,000, significantly below the area's usual prices. However, the property has only three years remaining on its lease, which would cost £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, similar to rental rates. The property, described as "unmodernised" and in need of renovation, is located in the exclusive Egerton Place and has 1,990 sq/ft of space. If a buyer extends the lease, the property's value could reach upwards of £6 million. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease for 90 years is expected to cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. Estate agents note that such properties with short leases are rare in Knightsbridge, and while the price seems low, the cost of lease extension is a significant factor. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson, and there is interest from locals, developers, and end users.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage that affected 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing sales registers to malfunction. The outage, which began on the east and west coasts, prevented staff from processing credit card payments, but cash transactions were still possible. In response, baristas gave away free drinks and baked goods, leading to excited customers sharing photos on social media. However, some stores closed early to avoid giving away free products. The company later resolved the issue, allowing stores to operate as usual. The outage occurred just one day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, where Muslims are being radicalized. Detective Constable Gareth Jones emphasized that terrorism is not limited to large cities and that individuals involved in such activities often engage in ordinary community activities with hidden motives. Historical incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales date back to 1998, when Abu Hamza sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons. The rugged terrain of these areas has also been used by the British military for training. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed in North Wales, and in 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested for planning a "Mumbai-style" attack. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead, linked to Iraqi clerics. Community intelligence is vital for authorities to identify and address such threats.

A rare Omura's whale, previously thought to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after a tropical cyclone. It is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68-meter juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling, as initial identification was difficult. The discovery is highly significant for scientists due to the limited knowledge about the species, which was first described in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The Omura's whale has a sleek body and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further study and potential public display.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Cheryl Rios's claim that Hillary Clinton should not be president due to female hormones potentially making her irrational and prone to unnecessary decisions, such as starting a war. It contrasts this with historical examples of male leaders whose decisions were also influenced by hormones, and highlights that studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. The passage further explores the broader issue of gender bias against women in leadership roles, emphasizing that the real challenge for female candidates like Clinton is not their biology, but societal bias. It argues that gender equality benefits everyone, from the economy to families, and calls for an end to gender stereotypes. The article also points out the irony in Rios's claim, noting that Canada already had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and portrayals of Winston Churchill, is auctioning off his extensive collection of over 200 antiques, including a hand-painted 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow, and various historical items, in a £100,000 sale. The auction, organized by Dominic Winter Auctioneers, features items reflecting his interests in military history and classic literature. Hardy, who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and is an expert on the medieval longbow, is downsizing his home and expressed sadness at parting with his treasured collection. The sale includes furniture, paintings, weapons, and books, with some items estimated to fetch up to £6,000. Hardy, 89, continues to pursue television work despite his retirement from stage acting.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, and has been on the run since Saturday. The body was discovered at their shared home in Winter Garden after an out-of-state family member called for a well-being check. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead. He is on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness and attempted suicide. His mother was helping him through a divorce, and his estranged wife had a domestic violence injunction against him. Neighbors believe the stress of the divorce and some bad news paperwork may have pushed him over the edge. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not yet confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without any provisions or medication. His estranged wife is preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a perceived unique strategic opportunity. This decision was made by the IAAF Council, who believed it was a chance to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF President, Lamine Diack, emphasized the strategic decision as a way to take advantage of a unique opportunity with support from public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, were also awarded without a bidding process. Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10,000 meters during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, into a trap to steal his winnings. Granger befriended Hassan, who was known for his lavish spending, and used her charm to gain his trust. She then allowed her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and his accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, to enter Hassan's flat, where they tied him up, brutally attacked him, and killed him while searching for his hidden cash. The trio stole £3,000 and other valuables before being caught through phone records. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter by a majority vote, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and received life sentences with a minimum of 36 years. The court described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," emphasizing the brutality and greed behind the crime.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has struggled in the second half of the season, evidenced by his poor performance in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland. Despite an initially strong start to the season, his form has significantly declined, affecting his contribution to both club and country. Fabregas, who was on track to break Thierry Henry's Premier League assists record, has only managed one assist in his last five games. His fatigue from playing almost every match for Chelsea has raised concerns about his durability. However, with nine games remaining, Fabregas and Chelsea still have a chance to secure the Premier League title if he can regain his form. His performance in the recent match against Hull City, where he provided an assist, could signal a potential late-season resurgence.

West Ham are in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford after he impressed on trial with the club's academy. Beckford, who has attracted interest from European clubs including those in Belgium, is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289, making it the cheapest pricing strategy in the Premier League to help fill the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman and joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, three months after the incident despite evidence pointing to a suspect. Lane was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes during a hunt in Everleigh, near Amesbury, where the riders were chasing an artificial scent. He suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. A video of the attack and evidence, including names and car registration numbers of saboteurs, were given to Wiltshire Police, but the investigation was shelved due to insufficient evidence. The suspect's face was captured on video, but he has not been identified. Hunt supporters and witnesses expressed frustration and disappointment with the decision, citing the lack of action and the challenges faced by police when dealing with face-covered offenders. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban face coverings for saboteurs to aid in criminal identification.

Adam Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was a prominent American-born member of al Qaeda who served as its chief English-language propagandist. He was born in 1978, converted to Islam in 1995, and left the United States for Pakistan in 1998, where he joined al Qaeda. Gadahn was known for his appearances in al Qaeda videos, where he encouraged attacks on American, Western, and Jewish interests and criticized U.S. presidents. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda and was among the FBI's most wanted terrorists. Gadahn was killed in January 2015 in a U.S. counterterrorism operation, along with Warren Weinstein, a U.S. hostage, and Ahmed Farouq, another U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative.

The passage discusses the passion of Chinese parents in raising child prodigies, highlighting a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo who has gained widespread attention for his exceptional basketball skills. He has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old and has displayed skills that rival professional players, such as scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs at once. His viral video has earned him numerous fans across China, with many netizens expressing amazement and even questioning if it was special effects. The passage also mentions Yao Ming, a well-known Chinese basketball star who played in the NBA.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the paedophile information exchange (PIE), which campaigned for the legalisation of child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, formed after the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning for a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson inquiry. O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off is an embarrassment to the group. PIE was formed in 1974 to campaign for the legalisation of sex with children and formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied for the age of sexual consent to be cut to ten. O'Carroll was on the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee and was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals." He wrote a blog after the February meeting, chaired by comedian John Cleese, confirming his attendance. A Hacked Off spokesman stated that the meeting was open to and free for all members of the public to attend.

The Icebergs Club pool at Bondi was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for the Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event, organized by the lifestyle brand "Ten Pieces," showcased a monochrome, unisex capsule collection of ten items designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall, with a backdrop of the ocean. The show took place on an unseasonably warm day with clear skies, and guests enjoyed nibbles and drinks while watching the androgynous designs. Passers-by and beachgoers gathered to watch the event, which was hosted by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent a day at a safari park in Northern California with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa. During the visit, he posed with and fed a rare white tiger, as well as interacted with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent after pressure to fight British rival Kell Brook in June. Khan had also been linked with bouts against Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman but stated he was already in negotiations for another fight.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, had his name removed from an Israeli memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl after his family and the organization Almagor objected. Abu Khdeir, 16, was killed in July by three Israelis, but his family and Almagor, which represents victims of terror, argued he was not a terror victim and should not be memorialized alongside soldiers or terrorism victims. The National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove his name following complaints. The case against the three suspects in his killing was being reviewed by a panel of judges.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden in an attempt to rest his head on the cat's belly. The cat initially allows the boy to rest on its belly but quickly moves away, prompting the boy to follow and repeat the action. This happens multiple times before the cat finally decides to leave. Later, the boy and cat reconcile, with the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia continues, with witness Robert Kushner losing his varsity coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his past marijuana sales. Kushner, 32, is one of many former drug dealers testifying against the police. He claimed that undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him in 2007. Despite passing a background check in 2010, Kushner's past arrests, including a 2011 probation sentence and a 2008 DUI, came to light, leading to his job loss. Kushner maintains he is innocent of the 2011 charges and claims he has moved past his past mistakes. His coaches and colleagues describe him as a dedicated and excellent coach. Defense lawyers for the accused officers argue that the government's case relies on unreliable witnesses.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China, caused a large fire, injuring six people, five of whom were hurt by broken glass and hospitalized. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, though no toxic chemical spill was reported. Over 600 firefighters were deployed to control the fire, which was brought under control by Tuesday morning. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical. The incident prompted local residents to share photos of the fire on social media. The plant, originally planned for Xiamen, was relocated to Zhangzhou in 2007 after public protests over pollution concerns. The plant had previously experienced an explosion in 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks. Construction of PX plants has sparked protests in several Chinese cities in recent years.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player, is known for wearing his socks low above his shinpads, a habit he considers a lifelong superstition and refuses to change, despite some referees' advice. He uses children's-sized shinpads and is confident this practice has protected him from injury so far. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, though the match was part of a tough relegation battle. He expressed gratitude for the opportunity and hopes to earn more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, she does not respond to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow people. She has a tracheostomy and has been in the same neurological state for nearly three months. Bobby Brown previously claimed his daughter was awake and watching him, but her condition has not improved significantly. An attorney for the family stated that while doctors believe she will live a long life, the quality of her life remains uncertain and will take years to determine.

Russia is leading Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup semi-final after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki in a closely contested match (4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3). Svetlana Kuznetsova earlier beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with her serve, committing 13 double faults, while Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proved crucial. With this result, Russia now needs just one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales (NSW) are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. The same weather system that caused severe flooding and damage last week, an East Coast Low, is expected to bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, particularly affecting the Hunter region, which has already suffered significant devastation. The State Emergency Service (SES) is still dealing with over 4,409 of 24,196 assistance requests from the previous storm and is concerned that new storms will hinder clean-up efforts. Meteorologists indicate that while the new storm may not be as severe as the previous one, it could still cause flooding in areas already saturated from last week's rain. The Bureau of Meteorology warns that heavy rainfall and strong winds are likely to impact coastal areas in the northeast of NSW and southeast Queensland. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's music video for "La Vida Loca," collapsed at home due to low blood pressure and was hospitalized. She posted photos of her injuries on Instagram, denying claims that she attempted suicide. Italian media reported that her boyfriend suggested she was a victim of people wanting to harm her, but Moric clarified that she had a domestic accident and was not trying to take her own life. She also mentioned that her ex-husband, Fabrizio Corona, a former paparazzi photographer who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities, had a complicated relationship with her. Moric is currently recovering at home.

A new YouGov survey for the Sunday Times reveals that the British public favor the name Diana for the second child of Kate and William, if it is a girl, as it honors William's late mother, Princess Diana. Diana received 12% of the votes, followed by Alice and Charlotte with 9% each. If the child is a boy, James is the preferred name with 13% of the votes. Many Brits hope for a girl, with a quarter of those polled wanting a female baby. Social media users expressed strong emotional support for naming a girl Diana. Additionally, the majority of Brits support William taking six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time in Khost, where the protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed it. The report was contributed by CNN journalists.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. During his seven years at Barcelona, he won four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. Alves was unable to agree on a new deal with the club, and his agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that he rejected a three-year contract extension, which was contingent on him playing in 60% of the club's matches. She stated that negotiations are over and criticized the club for not considering contract renewal earlier.

Pablo Osvaldo has encouraged Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo, who recently joined Boca on a loan from Southampton, believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a good fit for the team due to their playing style and abilities. He claims that the fans at Boca would love to see them play on the La Bombonera pitch. Pirlo is recognized as one of the best midfielders globally, while Totti is a Roma legend who Osvaldo thinks would be well-received in Argentina.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, suffered a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square during a race at Wincanton, which went viral online with hundreds of thousands of views. Despite the dramatic fall, Ferguson only sustained a minor cut on his nose and was back riding out the next day, showing no signs of being deterred from continuing his racing career. He described the incident as a blur and mentioned that other jockeys were shocked by the fall. Ferguson humorously considered a potential future in gymnastics due to the somersaults but remains focused on racing.

James Haskell, a rugby player and captain of London Wasps, dressed as Iron Man for an Instagram post to celebrate the release of the *Avengers: Age of Ultron* movie. The movie premiered in London, drawing large crowds to see the A-list cast including Robert Downey Jr. Haskell, who previously played for Wasps from 2002 to 2009, returned to the club in 2012 after stints in France, Japan, and New Zealand. Since his return, he has made over 100 appearances for Wasps and earned 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide-leg trousers as a key trend for spring/summer 2015. It highlights the appeal of wide-leg trousers as a stylish alternative to skinny jeans, emphasizing their effortless look and versatility. The trend has made a comeback, reminiscent of the 1970s, and has been featured on various catwalks, including Gucci and Celine. Tips for wearing wide-leg trousers include pairing them with high heels and simple tops to maintain proportion and avoid looking overwhelmed by the volume of fabric. Denim is highlighted as an easy way to achieve the look, with examples such as Gucci's vintage wash flared jeans and Topshop's Miller jeans. The trend is also accessible through affordable options like Finery London. The passage concludes by noting that wide-leg trousers are a versatile trend that can be worn regardless of the weather.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students who signed a petition against it. The film, starring Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history, was initially canceled due to concerns about its portrayal of the Iraq War and its potential negative impact on perceptions of the Middle East. However, the university reversed its decision, citing the importance of freedom of expression. A counter-petition emerged, and the screening will go ahead as part of the UMIX social events. For those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper," a screening of "Paddington" will be offered. The decision was praised by Michigan's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

A quokka was injured when two French tourists allegedly set an aerosol spray on fire with a lighter, causing a flame to make contact with the animal on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed. The two men, aged 18 and 24, were evicted from the island, charged with animal cruelty, and will appear in court on April 17. Quokkas, which are about the size of a domestic cat, are found on small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer from the 1930s and 1940s who performed at famous New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar alongside notable figures such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen any motion pictures or photographs of herself dancing. With the help of filmmakers, she was able to view early music videos called "soundies" that featured her performances, which she found delightful and described as "just fabulous."

A recent study by vehicle leasing firm OSV shows that washing one's own car is becoming less common in Britain, with a third of men and three-quarters of women never doing it. The decline is attributed to factors such as the rise of hand car washes, larger vehicles being harder to clean, and changes in lifestyle, such as more live football on TV and shops opening on Sundays. However, Brits are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, with 15 million cars cleaned during the recent Easter break. The study also found that cars in cities like Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield are most likely to be washed by their owners, while those in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh are least likely. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are more likely to wash their cars, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners are less likely.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard for his impact on him since joining Liverpool in 2008 and acknowledges Gerrard's significance to the club. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel believes Liverpool can overcome the challenge of replacing Gerrard and mentions potential players who can fill his role with the right support. Both Gerrard and Skrtel are expected to return for the Villa match after serving bans for violent conduct.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75, achieved a hole-in-one during the Par-3 Contest at Augusta National, adding to his storied career. This was his first ace at Augusta, though it was surpassed by Camilo Villegas, who recorded two aces but lost in a playoff to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, a legendary golfer, is a six-time Masters champion and one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens were activated in Kansas as multiple storms brought reports of tornadoes. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, moving northeast and missing Wichita but posing risks to other communities. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned about the dangers of nighttime tornadoes. Other tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Missouri was also affected, with a possible tornado touching down near Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding. Unusual weather conditions were also observed in nearby areas, with reports of baseball-sized hail. More storms were expected in the Midwest and surrounding regions on Thursday.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation. Bates claims the shooting was accidental, as he intended to use a taser but mistakenly used a gun. The judge allowed Bates to go on a vacation to the Bahamas, which upset Harris's family, who felt it showed apathy toward the incident. Bates's preliminary hearing is set for July 2. His lawyer claims his training documents prove he was qualified, while the Harris family's lawyer alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and connections. The sheriff's office denies these allegations. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 and has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, symbolizing his readiness to defeat Aldo. McGregor claims Aldo lacks the same motivation to defend his title for the eighth time as he has to win it. Their relationship is tense, and McGregor recently grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin, raising it in front of supporters.

Prime Minister Tony Abbott drew criticism for skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, with anti-drinking campaigners and cultural studies professor Julie Roberts arguing that his actions glorify binge drinking and associate masculinity with heavy alcohol consumption. Critics believe Abbott should set an example that one doesn't need to drink heavily to be a "true blue Aussie bloke." While some, like Health Minister Sussan Ley, defended Abbott's actions, Roberts warned that such displays can encourage irresponsible drinking and perpetuate harmful stereotypes. Abbott's behavior was seen as out of step with current attitudes toward binge drinking, which have become more concerned than in the past.

Indiana has experienced a significant rise in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, linked to intravenous drug use, particularly involving the painkiller Opana. This marks a sharp increase from 106 cases the previous week. Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program to address the outbreak, which has distributed over 5,000 clean syringes and collected 1,400 used ones. Health officials expect the number of cases to rise as more testing occurs, and there is pressure to extend the program beyond its initial 30-day limit. While Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy, some lawmakers support expanding such programs to other high-risk counties. However, the federal ban on public funding for these programs raises concerns about their long-term sustainability. A bill allowing needle exchanges in other counties is under consideration, but its future remains uncertain.

Saskia, an Arsenal fan's girlfriend, took a comprehensive football quiz created by her boyfriend to test her knowledge of Arsenal. She scored 43.5 out of 50, earning an A grade and avoiding being dumped. The quiz included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and an "in your own words" section, with instructions similar to a school exam. Saskia struggled with some questions, such as naming all 11 players in the starting squad and understanding player positions. However, she received double marks for her creative answer on why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard. Her boyfriend marked her answers with red pen and drew angry faces when she got questions wrong. Saskia shared the test on her Twitter account, sparking reactions from followers, some of whom praised her boyfriend as a "legend" and called Saskia "proper gf material." Others, however, thought the test was excessive. Overall, the situation was seen as a humorous and lighthearted way to show Arsenal fandom.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, became an undercover DEA informant in the 1980s after fleeing Colombia due to a confrontation with his boss. He provided crucial information that led to the prosecution of high-profile figures such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Toro worked for the DEA for 27 years, assisting in undercover operations globally, but was never granted U.S. citizenship as promised. After retiring due to health issues, he is now facing deportation and living illegally in the U.S. The DEA refused to assist him with citizenship, leaving him in legal limbo. Toro fears for his life if deported to Colombia and has received financial help from a former colleague, but he remains unable to secure a green card or passport, preventing him from collecting social security benefits.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is currently in critical condition in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The incident occurred when she went outside her house to relieve herself. Her brother tried to extinguish the flames, and she screamed for help. The accused men have been arrested. This incident comes amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following recent protests and the banning of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old student, Jyoti Singh. The documentary highlighted the brutal attack on Jyoti, which led to widespread protests and outrage. Other recent incidents include a mob beating a man to death for allegedly raping an 11-year-old girl and footage of a prolonged attack on an 18-year-old girl in Nagaland. These events have fueled calls for better protection for women in India.

Louis Van Gaal, the Manchester United manager, is looking forward to the derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford but will be without Robin Van Persie due to fitness concerns, despite Van Persie claiming he is fit. Van Gaal also ruled out Luke Shaw for similar reasons.
