The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which lost control of key northern states and the presidential election for the first time. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP retained control in some southern states, including Rivers, but lost several key regions. The APC's gains have weakened the PDP, which now appears as a regional party. The PDP's failure to secure a national spread of votes, along with internal issues like corruption and defections, contributed to its loss. The APC did not win any of the five oil-producing states, which could pose challenges for Buhari's administration due to potential disruptions in oil revenue. The elections saw some violence, but were generally more peaceful than in previous years, indicating progress in Nigeria's democracy.

Mighty, a US-based environmental group, has accused Singapore-based agricultural company Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of contributing to the haze in Southeast Asia by sourcing palm oil from suppliers that may be involved in unsustainable and illegal practices. Olam denies the allegations, stating it has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" sourcing policy and is working to verify its suppliers. Temasek, a state-owned investment company, also denies the allegations, emphasizing that it does not direct the operations of its portfolio companies. The report also criticizes the palm oil industry for its environmental impact, including deforestation and burning, and highlights similar concerns in Gabon, where Olam is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations. The report suggests that the industry faces challenges in ensuring sustainable practices, with conflicting views between environmental groups and industry executives.
A new law introduced on 27 August 2016 allows dogs to eat at restaurants, but only outdoors. As a result, a restaurant started serving puppy platters, which are meals for dogs.

Fernando Forestieri is uncertain to play due to a knee injury, having only been a substitute in the last two games. David Nugent may return after missing a recent match with a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield is seeking a recall after scoring a late goal off the bench.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator has lifted the ban on YouTube, which was previously imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims." The ban was lifted after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube, allowing the government to request content blocking directly from Google. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the lifting of the ban, activists have called for more transparency regarding the agreement between Google and the government. YouTube has stated that it will review government requests for content removal and only act if the content violates its community guidelines or is illegal in the country. The film "Innocence of Muslims" sparked protests in Pakistan, highlighting the sensitive issue of blasphemy in the country.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is a Swiss-Italian national, as is Gianni Infantino, one of the presidential candidates. Scala previously stepped aside in 2015 due to a conflict of interest with Swiss candidate Sepp Blatter. Now, Musa Bility, head of the Liberian FA, is threatening to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw from the upcoming election, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations, which bars committee members with conflicts of interest. Scala's spokesperson argues there is no such rule and that his previous withdrawal was a voluntary precaution, not a requirement. The election to replace Blatter will occur in 18 days, with five candidates: Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale. Bility, who was previously denied eligibility to run, has pledged his support to Prince Ali and is urging African members to do the same.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in an explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search was conducted, and Det Ch Insp Paul Durham indicated significant progress had been made, suggesting the incident involved a flashover explosion caused by a buildup of toxic fumes and an ignition source, leading to a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against Caf, but they avoided disqualification by apologizing. Morocco was able to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifiers after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban and reduced their fine. Morocco had previously been punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup, citing fears over Ebola, and was replaced by Equatorial Guinea, which had only 64 days to prepare. Tunisia's participation in the 2015 Nations Cup was marred by a controversial penalty decision that led to a dispute with Caf, which was resolved when Tunisia apologized. Both Tunisia and Morocco are now set to compete in the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia aiming for a record 13th consecutive appearance.

In a 3-1 victory for Chelsea at Etihad Stadium, Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off. Aguero received a four-match ban for his second dismissal this season for violent conduct, while Fernandinho got a three-match ban after clashing with Cesc Fabregas. Chelsea's Fabregas will not face further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs have until 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot program in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd focusing on patients without clear cancer symptoms, aiming to improve early diagnosis. Inspired by Denmark's diagnostic systems, which have improved cancer survival rates, the program seeks to address delays in diagnosis for patients without obvious symptoms. Doctors hope to refer these patients to diagnostic centers quickly, reducing the time to diagnosis and treatment. Currently, only 35% of patients with suspicious symptoms receive a diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area, so the initiative aims to reach more patients early. A similar clinic will be established in Port Talbot as part of a trial by the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg Health Board. Experts believe the program could significantly improve patient outcomes by enabling faster diagnosis and treatment. If successful, the pilot will be expanded across the region.

England secured a significant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a large margin of runs. England's total of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared set up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was the man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. He also took four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it one of the best he has seen. Root, who had previously struggled in the first Test, stated that he focused on correcting his errors and played more controlled cricket. Coach Trevor Bayliss noted that Root had done soul-searching and hard work before returning to form. Pakistan's performance was criticized, with their spirit broken and only two players scoring over 50 in the first two Tests. Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment, citing lack of confidence and poor shot selection as reasons for their loss. The series is expected to be tight, with the third Test set to take place at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley as interim coach. Forwards coach McBryde will take on head coaching responsibilities for the third time, having previously led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is in advanced discussions to appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour and aims to finalize the management team soon. WRU chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches on the tour will benefit Welsh rugby by providing valuable development opportunities and inspiring players and coaches.

Hull City ended a six-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over Southampton. Charlie Austin scored a penalty in the sixth minute, giving Southampton an early lead. However, Hull made a strong second-half comeback, with Robert Snodgrass scoring a goal and setting up a header from Michael Dawson. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, David Marshall's saves and a last-minute goalline clearance by Sam Clucas secured the win for Hull. The victory was significant for Hull, as it was their first league win since August 20. The match took place against a backdrop of low attendance and fan dissatisfaction, but Snodgrass's performance lifted both the team and the crowd. Southampton's manager, Claude Puel, acknowledged the team's lack of concentration, while Hull's manager, Mike Phelan, praised his players' resilience and the timing of the international break for recovery.

A collision occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 near Thornton, close to Woodhall Spa. A local motorcyclist was killed, while the tractor driver involved was not injured. Lincolnshire Police have requested witnesses to come forward and closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, aiming to "put an end to the agony" before early elections. This decision faced condemnation from both the opposition and EU officials. The turmoil began in 2015 with the release of recordings suggesting government ministers plotted vote-rigging and covered up a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev claims the government wiretapped 20,000 people and revealed corruption, while the government denies these accusations and accuses Zaev of destabilizing the country. EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn criticized the move as undermining the rule of law and risking Macedonia's EU membership.

Swansea City will be managed by Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams for their upcoming match against Bournemouth following the sacking of Bob Bradley. The club is looking to appoint a new permanent manager, with Paul Clement being the top choice. Curtis expresses concerns about the difficulty of returning to the Premier League if Swansea is relegated, noting the increased strength of the Championship and the challenges faced by other clubs. Swansea was promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after a remarkable rise from near bankruptcy and near relegation in 2003. Curtis believes the club has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, citing frequent changes in management and the dilution of the "Swansea Way." He believes the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League and emphasizes the importance of maintaining the club's progress to the players.

Dagenham & Redbridge, who reached League One in 2010 and were promoted to the Football League in 2007, were relegated back to the National League after a 3-2 loss to Leyton Orient. The defeat ended their survival hopes, with Armand Gnanduillet scoring the decisive goal. Dagenham struggled this season, with the worst goal difference in League Two and a significant drop in attacking performance compared to previous seasons. Manager John Still, who previously led the club from the Conference to League One, aims to help Dagenham gain promotion from the National League next season. Meanwhile, Leyton Orient's play-off hopes remain alive after the win, though they are two points behind the play-off spots. The victory came after the removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan, with interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasizing the importance of professionalism and winning games to secure a play-off spot.

Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player. He had discussions with manager Jürgen Klopp, who expressed confidence in Gerrard's potential as a future manager. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and won multiple trophies with the club, retired in November after a 19-year career. He had previously been linked with a managerial role at MK Dons but felt it was too soon. Gerrard is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, necessary for managing in the Premier League.

In the match described, McManus scored early, followed by Ross Forbes with a deflected goal, giving Morton a 2-0 lead. Alloa responded with a goal from Kyle McAusland before halftime. Morton then secured a comfortable win with additional goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone.

Ofsted has discovered evidence of children being taught in unsanitary conditions in three closed schools in Birmingham, with the owners under investigation for running illegal schools, which could result in up to 51 weeks in jail. The government is consulting on stricter regulations for schools operating more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed concern that these cases are only the "tip of the iceberg," and children may be at risk of abuse or radicalization. Ofsted has visited 18 unregulated schools, mostly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, and believes some are exploiting home education laws to run illegal schools. The Education Secretary has requested Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools, with her consent required for prosecution. The consultation on further regulation will run until mid-January, and the government has funded a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools. Sir Michael emphasized that the regulations apply to all religious groups.

Lilliard Gin is set to open at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, marking the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders in nearly 200 years. The gin, named after a legendary Borders heroine, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor, uses local botanicals to reflect the region's unique "terroir." The distillery, led by Kate Macinnes, operates on a small scale with a production still that fits in a cowshed, emphasizing local sourcing and a focus on the local flavor palette. The project aligns with the ethos of the Scottish Borders Brewery on the same site.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died when Gary Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit, reversed his vehicle into him at Swithens Farm near Leeds. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed that the family's life was "changed forever" and emphasized the importance of not driving under the influence, whether on public or private land. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks under health and safety legislation, as the incident occurred on private land. The Health and Safety Executive described the incident as "extremely tragic" and Green's behavior as "reckless."

Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguay striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches by his new club, Barcelona, following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Although he remains banned from competitive matches for eight games, he can now participate in football-related activities, including training sessions and promotional events. His public presentation as a Barcelona player will take place at Camp Nou on Monday. Suarez's appeal against a four-month ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup was unsuccessful, but Cas deemed the original punishment excessive by preventing him from any football activity. The ruling allows him to take part in Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. His legal team argued that Fifa had misapplied its rules, and while Cas confirmed the sanctions, it acknowledged the need for proportionality in disciplinary actions. Suarez, who moved to Barcelona for £75m, has a history of disciplinary issues, including previous suspensions for biting and racially abusing opponents.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, slopes, and water pistols. Competitors could be any combination, including men carrying women, men carrying men, or women carrying women. Richard and Anna will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses concerns raised by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges regarding potential job losses at the DVLA due to the transition from paper-based car tax discs to an electronic system. Stephen Hammond, the minister, assured that while changes in job roles and a reduction in refunds might occur, the government plans to redeploy staff to other areas of the business rather than resorting to redundancies. The new system, introduced in October 2014, allows for monthly direct debit payments, eliminating the need for tax discs. Hedges acknowledged the benefits of the changes and welcomed the commitment to redeployment.

Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has refused to backtrack on three controversial laws, including one that could close the Central European University (CEU) founded by George Soros, strict controls on asylum seekers, and legislation targeting NGOs. These laws have drawn criticism from the EU and human rights groups, with the EU objecting to Hungary's domestic policies. The EU could not strip Hungary of its voting rights without unanimous approval, and Hungary has secured Poland's support to veto any such move. The government maintains that these laws are a matter of national competence and asserts that European institutions should not interfere with domestic issues.

The passage summarizes the casting and production details for a live-action adaptation of Disney's "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson plays Belle, Dan Stevens plays the Beast, and Luke Evans plays Gaston, with Josh Gad as LeFou. Kevin Kline plays Maurice, and the star of the film will play Mrs. Potts, a role previously voiced by Angela Lansbury. Bill Condon directs, and filming begins in May 2017 at Shepperton Studios. The film is set for release on 17 March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and writer for the Sunday Times, was diagnosed with multiple cancers and passed away recently, shocking colleagues and friends. Known for his sharp wit, fearless writing, and unique style, Gill was celebrated as a "giant among journalists" and a significant figure in the paper since 1993. Despite his illness, he remained stoical and expressed gratitude for his life. His work often sparked controversy, including controversial comments on various topics and people, but he was also admired for his eloquence and brilliance. Gill overcame dyslexia to build a successful career, having written for various publications before joining the Sunday Times. He had two marriages and several children. His final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, was published in the Sunday Times.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator. He was reportedly hit over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face. His father stated that he suffered a serious brain injury and was in a coma for 10 days. Sukhbaatar was wearing a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika, a symbol with historical significance in Mongolia that predates its association with Nazi Germany. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but claims local media reports are "distorted." The alleged attacker, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been arrested, as the injury was not deemed serious. The case is under investigation, and the suspect's diplomatic status is not a factor in the legal process. The rapper's lawyer and family denied claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the show.

Plane Stupid campaigners protested against the airport's expansion plans by staging a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area. The protesters will appear in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police stated that security at the airport will be reviewed.

Glamorgan's innings was led by Nick Selman's 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, which marked a return to form after a string of low scores. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets, keeping Glamorgan's total in check. Aneurin Donald contributed 36 off 30 balls. Glamorgan's bowlers, Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten, earned a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire's innings was a struggle, with the day ending evenly balanced. Glamorgan is led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck injury. Both Selman and Taylor provided commentary on the match, with Selman expressing hope to continue his good form and Taylor commenting on the effectiveness of their bowling strategy.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after communicating with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to making two threats to ambush and shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary, which were made while he was drunk and late at night. Hughes intended to make a false report to police to lure them to the scene. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody pending sentencing, noting his 2009 conviction for possessing a firearm. Hughes's legal team previously argued he had no intention of carrying out the threats, but the court expressed concern due to his bail status for prior firearms offences. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to those in need.

Yorkshire were reduced to 8-2 but managed to score 255-7, with a notable stand of 130 between Davies and Ben Foakes (90). However, their run-chase was derailed by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst in nine balls, which included dismissing Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire were all out for 236. They had previously lost to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals and aimed to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002. Their innings started strongly with Dominic Sibley and Kumar Sangakkara, but errors by Matthew Waite and others led to crucial losses. Meaker's performance turned the game, and despite Bresnan and Waite's efforts, Yorkshire fell short in the final overs. Surrey's captain praised Davies and Foakes' partnership, while Yorkshire's captain expressed disappointment, acknowledging their strong season but failing to perform when it mattered most.

A 56ft converted trawler encountered flooding issues 6 miles west of South Stack, prompting the crew to contact coastguards at 07:00 BST. The onboard pump was insufficient to handle the water intake, leading the RNLI lifeboat crew to deploy a pump and tow the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle distance runner, will not participate in next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies, which conflict with the event's timing in April. She recently achieved a personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, finishing sixth. Muir plans to focus on her studies, aiming to complete her degree, and is considering future competitions such as the World Indoor Championships in March and potentially multiple Olympics. She expressed disappointment at missing the Commonwealth Games but remains optimistic about her athletic future.

The passage discusses Liverpool's struggles to replicate last season's title challenge, highlighting issues with their current squad, particularly in the forward line after losing Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge. Steven Gerrard is mentioned as facing a physical and mental battle to secure a long-term future with the club. The article also analyzes Liverpool's tactical shortcomings, such as a lack of intensity, poor set-piece performance, and defensive instability. The author predicts a tough match against Chelsea, emphasizing the need for Liverpool to improve significantly to compete. Lastly, it touches on Gerrard's resilience and his importance to the team despite his age and past mistakes.

The passage describes a £45m educational facility in Kilmarnock, set to include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. The East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after the late William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was a passionate advocate for education, transitioning from teaching to writing in 1975. He gained fame with his novel "Remedy Is None" and became known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for his Glasgow-based works like the Laidlaw trilogy. He was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributed to Scottish political and sporting life. McIlvanney passed away on 5 December at his Glasgow home.

An area near a swimming pool in the town was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon, with nearby residents advised to stay indoors and keep windows open. An exclusion zone was in place on the river due to a sea mine, believed to be British from the 1940s or 1950s, spotted on Monday. The evacuation affected three streets, with safety advice issued to those within 500m of the mine. A sea exclusion zone of about half a mile was also established, and small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. Ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay were disrupted. Authorities emphasized the evacuation was precautionary and there was no immediate danger. Due to the mine's deterioration, it was moved to a safer location for handling. Local officials thanked residents for their patience during the operation.

The passage discusses changes in funding for various Olympic and Paralympic sports in the UK ahead of the Tokyo 2020 Games. Several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton, have had their funding cut, with badminton being particularly affected as it was the only sport that achieved a podium finish in Rio but still lost its funding. Cycling also saw a significant reduction in funding. UK Sport has allocated £345m to 31 sports, £2m less than the Rio Games, with targets set for 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals. While some sports like judo received slight funding increases, others, such as basketball, handball, and volleyball, have faced previous funding cuts and are critical of UK Sport's approach. UK Sport emphasizes the need to prioritize investment to maintain success, while some sports argue that team sports are being neglected. Funding for new sports added to the Tokyo programme, such as baseball/softball, karate, and others, is still under consideration.

Three Victorian hotels in East Cliff, Bournemouth, will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel with 90 rooms and two assisted-living apartment blocks (totaling 122 apartments). The development, supported by councillors with a 7-3 vote, aims to boost tourism and improve living conditions for older residents. English Heritage and local groups, including the Ancient Monuments Society, opposed the plan, citing concerns about the impact on the conservation area's historic character. Despite objections, the council proceeded, with the developer, The East Cliff Project LLP, set to demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The plan received 246 letters of support and 49 letters of objection.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, was attacked and killed during a night out in Brecon. He was punched and beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, outside a bar called The Cellar. Vallely then dragged Boyd's unconscious body and fled the scene. CCTV footage showed the attack, and Vallely had been drinking heavily before the incident. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of involvement as he left the scene before the violence began. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. Pte Boyd, who was training at the infantry battle school, was described as a loving, caring, and loyal individual with a promising future. His family expressed deep sorrow, stating that Vallely's actions created an "unbearable pain" and a "void" in their lives. The community's support for the family was highlighted as a testament to the strength of the people in Brecon.

Andrew Travers left his position by mutual agreement following an error that caused voters to be turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and a council spokesperson acknowledged Travers' contributions during his three-and-a-half years as chief executive. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. On election day, only three out of the first 30 voters at one station were registered, leading to concerns about the fairness of the process. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes. Travers attributed the issues to electoral registration lists, and a review will conclude by the end of May, assessing the arrangements for the EU Referendum.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a match where Josh Gillies scored a free-kick to give Gateshead the lead, but Wrexham equalized before halftime with a set-piece from Sean Newton. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a header from a cross by Craig Baxter. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, praised the team's improvement in the second half and the quality of the winning goal. Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment with their second-half performance and noted missed opportunities. The match ended with Gateshead claiming the victory.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan and Mozambique are ranked lowest.

The passage discusses the OneWeb project, which aims to create a global satellite constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide broadband internet access worldwide, including to every school. This ambitious project requires a significant shift in satellite manufacturing, with Airbus leading the development of high-volume, low-cost production methods, akin to assembly lines in car and plane factories. The first assembly line is in Toulouse, France, with more planned in Florida. The project involves launching satellites in large batches using over 20 Soyuz rockets, aiming to have 300 satellites in orbit by the end of 2020 and over 800 by mid-decade. OneWeb and Airbus emphasize debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit satellites within two years and using additional hardware to manage space debris. While OneWeb has raised $1.7 billion and seeks further financing, it faces competition from other companies like SpaceX and Boeing. The UK Space Agency is involved in licensing and regulatory oversight, highlighting the economic and environmental implications of the project.

The UK government's recent spending review has placed significant pressure on public expenditure in Scotland, with Scottish ministers receiving an additional £390m in spending for the next year. However, the Scottish government argues that cumulative cuts since 2010, along with the latest review, will result in a 12.5% real-term reduction in their discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. Mr Swinney, the Scottish finance minister, emphasizes that over £1bn in cuts are still to come and criticizes the UK government's austerity approach, stating that Scotland's priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service will not be compromised. The UK government highlights the increased funding and stability of the UK economy, suggesting that Scotland's current financial arrangement is more beneficial than independence. Labour criticizes the Scottish government for not providing a long-term budget and proposes alternative fiscal policies.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families due to the lack of suitable toilet facilities. While ordinary accessible toilets may suffice for some wheelchair users, they are inadequate for those requiring additional support like hoists or two carers. Changing Places toilets, which are larger and equipped with extra features, are recommended for larger buildings but are not currently compulsory. Campaigners, like Lorna Fillingham, are pushing for these toilets to be made mandatory in new developments to ensure accessibility and reduce the stress and stigma faced by disabled individuals and their families. Despite the challenges of installation, some businesses, like Arsenal Football Club, have successfully implemented these facilities, highlighting the positive impact on inclusivity and customer experience.

Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission, alleging that McDonald's forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, limiting their ability to switch to competitors due to long contracts. McDonald's claims it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, which it says has been successful for many years. Unions, including the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and the Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union, support the antitrust complaint, arguing that McDonald's abuse of its dominant market position harms franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are found to be valid. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and the company earned $9.27bn in revenue from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A poster with the hashtag #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood, part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign began as a Facebook and Instagram hashtag by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works, and went viral, receiving significant global support. A mystery donor paid for a billboard in Holywood to support Josh, and there has been a large outpouring of support on Twitter from his classmates and people worldwide. The campaign has raised awareness and brought together global support for Josh's recovery.

The passage discusses the UK government's decision to close Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Wales, as part of a broader military reorganization. Local MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the closure, citing the barracks' long history and its significance to the community, including military tourism and employment. While jobs are not expected to be at risk, concerns are raised about the impact on the local economy and the lack of respect for the barracks' heritage. The reorganization includes establishing a new light infantry center at St Athan and closing other bases like Cawdor Barracks in 2024. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary acknowledges the need for restructuring but warns of potential negative effects on affected individuals.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that the fishing communities, which largely voted to leave the EU, may be at risk of being overlooked in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which granted equal access to fishing grounds for all member states, was unpopular in the UK, and Brexit is seen by some as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation, similar to Norway. However, the House of Lords report warns of potential trade-offs, noting that the UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters in exchange for continued market access to the EU. The report also emphasizes the need to retain scientific-based quotas and cooperation with neighboring states. While the fishing industry remains optimistic about Brexit, the report cautions against marginalizing the sector in negotiations. The UK's fishing industry is small in terms of GDP and employment, but the report stresses the importance of maintaining market access and sustainable fisheries management.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA employee, leaked documents revealing that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has extensive surveillance capabilities, including access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, and social media information. The NSA, through programs like Prism, has been able to access data from major tech companies such as Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, and Apple, although these companies have denied involvement. The US government confirmed it requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and phone numbers. While the NSA claims these operations help keep Americans secure, critics argue that such surveillance infringes on privacy rights. Data protection laws vary by country, but they typically regulate how companies handle data rather than government activities. The US Patriot Act of 2001 allows US authorities to access data stored abroad, raising concerns about privacy for non-Americans. The UK and EU have expressed concerns over the implications of the Prism program, with the EU seeking more details from the US. Privacy advocates argue that the existence of Prism confirms fears about global surveillance, with the US government having access to vast amounts of data with little transparency or recourse for individuals.

Open AI, backed by figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to develop artificial intelligence (AI) with a focus on positive human impact, free from financial obligations. The organization emphasizes the importance of ensuring AI benefits society and is distributed broadly and safely. While some experts, including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, warn of AI's potential existential threat to humanity, others argue the risk remains remote. Open AI plans to use only a small portion of the $1bn pledged in the coming years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, was nominated to carry the Olympic torch despite a brain injury that took his speech. He now speaks unaided and is determined to prove everyone wrong. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, walks with crutches, and raises money for military charities. He has received thousands of Facebook friend requests, but the site limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. His mother, Diane, said the support has been phenomenal, and the family has received an overwhelming amount of messages and emails. Facebook suggested he consider a public page or subscription feature to manage the requests. A total of 8,000 people will carry the Olympic flame on its journey to the opening ceremony in London.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, with no change from the previous three years. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, the first increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance dropped to 15.7%. The US poverty rate reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, moved to Lancashire (the Red Rose) from Somerset in 2013 and signed a new contract keeping him with the club until 2019. He is a short-format specialist, having scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent, contribution to the team's success in the T20 Blast final, and his positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, is set to return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with bidders finalizing their proposals for the sale. No preservation proposals have been submitted yet, and viewings are scheduled for late February and March, with a decision expected in the spring. The Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, a local MP, supports UK recyclers but prefers to save at least one ship for a noble second life, such as a reef or diving attraction, which could generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options for the best financial return for the taxpayer. The Type 22 frigates were originally anti-submarine ships that evolved into powerful combatants with advanced systems and were used as flagships. Last year, the HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3m.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced ongoing racial and political tensions, leading to multiple coups and international isolation. A 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew an Indian-dominated government, followed by a 2000 coup that resulted in the hostage situation of the prime minister and his cabinet. These events harmed the economy, especially tourism, and damaged Fiji's international reputation. A 2006 military coup marked the fourth in 20 years, leading to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. Free elections in 2014 led to the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and Fiji's reinstatement in the Commonwealth. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the former now having a slight majority due to Indo-Fijian emigration. The economy relies on sugar, tourism, and mining, but faces challenges like trade deficits and heavy reliance on foreign aid.

Syria is working to comply with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, though it missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. A shipment of weapons was attacked on its way to the port of Latakia, according to Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad, who blamed terrorist groups. He criticized the US for condemning Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo and accused the US of supporting terrorist elements. Reports indicate that rebels may have seized Aleppo's central prison, which holds at least 3,000 detainees. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 4% (30 tonnes) having been removed so far. The US and Russia are urging Syria to meet the deadline for transferring the weapons to the coast by 1 March, with the OPCW acknowledging that security concerns have slowed the process. Syria claims it is committed to fulfilling its obligations under the UN and OPCW agreements.

The passage discusses the shortlisted books for the 2014 Booker Prize, highlighting the core pieces of information. Mukherjee's *The Lives of Others* is the favorite to win, with bookmakers William Hill listing it at 5/2. This year marks the first time the prize is open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and an Australian. Howard Jacobson, a former Booker winner, is nominated for *J*, a futuristic love story. Other shortlisted authors include Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. The passage also provides details on each book's plot, sales figures, and commentary from critics and academics. Fowler's *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves* is the best-selling among the shortlisted novels. The judging panel, chaired by AC Grayling, will announce the winner at London's Guildhall, with coverage on BBC News and BBC Arts.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in the media in England and Wales. The UK Supreme Court will now consider whether to grant his appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction will remain in place until the hearing concludes. The case involves allegations of PJS having extra-marital affairs, including a three-way encounter in 2011. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish the story, but PJS claims his right to privacy. Initially, a High Court judge refused to impose an injunction, but the appeal court later ruled in PJS's favor, preventing his identification. However, the appeal court judges later determined that the details of the allegations were too widespread for a permanent injunction to be effective, making it a "hopeless task" to maintain confidentiality.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was recently purchased for £345.5 million. The new owners, in collaboration with Blaby District Council, plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the park. Ernie White, the council leader, emphasized the park's role as a gateway to the city and the potential for enhancement. Paul Clarke from Crown Estates highlighted the focus on upgrading common areas and facilities to rejuvenate the site.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving a character named LeFou. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit regarding this scene, but the release was postponed for a content review. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, but the tourism minister criticized the ban as "ridiculous." The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification" and local cinema chains offered refunds for pre-purchased tickets. The decision to review the film drew criticism from netizens who found it unreasonable.

Summary: Landlords in Southampton who rent properties to more than three unrelated people must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost up to ??1,000, though non-compliance can lead to fines of up to ??20,000. The city estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs. Tenants often face issues like fear of eviction and poor living conditions. Nationally, HMO licensing applies to properties with five or more unrelated occupants in buildings of three storeys or more. In Southampton, licensing applies to specific areas, with some resistance from landlords, though the council has taken legal action against a few.

The Acting Taoiseach, Enda Kenny of Fine Gael, and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to prevent a second election. Fianna Fáil is willing to support a minority government but not a full programme for government. Disagreements over water charges are a major obstacle, with Fianna Fáil wanting their immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting their continuation. A commission to review the future of Irish Water is being considered. After the recent election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, but no party could form a majority government, and a taoiseach has not yet been elected.

The Sorrento, an Italian ferry, caught fire on one of its car decks while traveling near Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca. The fire quickly spread, leading to the evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats, which were later rescued by the Puglia ferry. At least three people were injured, with one in serious condition, and were taken to the hospital by helicopter. The cause of the fire was unclear, and the ship may sink due to the damage. The passengers were expected to return to Palma de Mallorca, with psychologists being sent to the port to provide counseling. The ferry sent out distress signals, and several ships were dispatched to assist. Initially, the captain did not think evacuation was necessary, but the fire's intensity led to a full evacuation.

The passage discusses issues surrounding voter registration and potential duplicate voting in the UK's 8 June general election. The Electoral Commission noted that 38 MPs raised concerns about individuals, including students, potentially voting twice, which is a criminal offense. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote, with a high turnout of 68.7%. However, there were concerns about duplicate applications, with estimates suggesting between 30% to 70% of applications could be duplicates. The lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration system has made it difficult to identify duplicates, leading to administrative and financial burdens. The watchdog recommended clearer information and a verification function, similar to systems in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland. Labour cautioned against making it harder for young people and students to register, emphasizing the need to balance preventing fraud with ensuring accessibility.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player known for his time at the University of Nebraska and for playing for teams like the St. Louis Rams and San Francisco 49ers, struggled with legal and personal issues throughout his life. After his NFL career, he faced multiple convictions, including assault charges, and was serving a prison sentence of over 30 years. He was recently accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward, and was set to face trial. Officials believe Phillips took his own life, though the method remains unclear. His former coach, Tom Osborne, acknowledged Phillips' intelligence and good qualities but also noted his struggles with anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal in Chester, awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams. This marks eight years of the regiment and makes him the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny. He joined the regiment in 2014, has an army number, is paid for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. He has participated in events like switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial event.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in a thrilling Europa League quarter-final match at Anfield. The game was marked by intense emotion, excitement, and a display of sheer willpower from Liverpool, who overcame a 2-0 deficit to eventually win. This victory was seen as a significant step towards earning a place in the Champions League. Manager Jurgen Klopp inspired his team by invoking the spirit of Liverpool's 2005 Champions League victory against AC Milan, and his passionate leadership was a key factor in the team's comeback. The match was also notable for the passionate atmosphere at Anfield, with fans playing a crucial role in the team's turnaround. Despite the win, Liverpool still has defensive vulnerabilities that Klopp plans to address in the summer. The victory has instilled a sense of belief in the team and fans, echoing the spirit of past great Liverpool moments.

The passage discusses a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where the UK government, represented by Mr. Davis, committed to keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations. Mr. Davis proposed monthly meetings to facilitate a "two-way information flow" with the devolved administrations. However, Mr. Russell from the Scottish government emphasized the need for greater transparency and clarity on the UK government's strategic intentions, particularly regarding EU market access. He stressed the importance of Scotland's membership in the single market for its economic prosperity. Additionally, the passage mentions the UK government's hope that the High Court's decision on triggering Article 50 will be overturned on appeal, while the Scottish government plans to oppose this in the Supreme Court.

The passage discusses a study on cloned sheep, including Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane, who are clones of Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal. These sheep are being closely monitored by researchers at the University of Nottingham to assess their health and aging processes. The study aims to determine whether cloned animals age normally and if they are more prone to age-related diseases such as osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. The research is significant as it could influence the future of cloning technology. So far, the cloned sheep appear to be in good health, with no significant differences observed in their health compared to the general sheep population.

Shutter Speed, an unbeaten favorite, won a race by a length and three quarters, beating Vintage Folly. She will go to Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom, where Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas. Shutter Speed's win was noted for her performance on soft ground, with trainer John Gosden pleased to have time to prepare her for Chantilly. Gosden is concerned about the ground for Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and may decide not to run him in the Derby trial due to the short time between the Dante and the Derby.

The passage discusses the fluctuating value of the British pound (sterling) in response to the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit referendum. Initially, the pound fell against the dollar, euro, and yen, but later showed signs of recovery before declining again. The volatility index reached levels similar to those during the 2008 financial crisis, indicating high investor uncertainty. Recent polls suggested the Leave campaign was gaining ground, leading to a drop in the implied probability of a Remain vote. Analysts anticipate increased volatility in the pound if polls remain tight as the referendum approaches. Markets globally, including Asian stock indices, experienced declines due to Brexit concerns, while the FTSE 100 also fell. Despite this, some Leave campaigners argued that the pound had actually strengthened since March and pointed out that a weaker pound could benefit UK exporters.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, just one point and one place away from the play-off spots. After a tough match against Barrow, which extended Barrow's unbeaten league run to nine games and continued Braintree's three-game losing streak, manager Cowley expressed both the challenges faced and the team's determination. He acknowledged the difficulty of the journey, noting the team's part-time status and the toughest challenge they've faced, but remained positive and committed to embracing the experience.

The passage discusses changes in Northern Ireland's planning system, where from April 2015, local councils will take responsibility for planning decisions previously handled by the Planning Service. This shift will place elected politicians in charge of most planning decisions, potentially increasing democratic involvement but raising concerns about the skills and integrity of politicians. Michael Corr of PLACE sees this as an opportunity for local development, while Friends of the Earth warns of potential unfairness and lack of transparency, referencing past issues of discrimination and close ties between developers and politicians. There is also debate over the regulation of political donations and the relevance of donation limits in Northern Ireland.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, resulting in the amputation of its left back leg and severe shoulder injuries. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, expressed concern over the powerful air gun used and the potential danger to children in the area. The Scottish SPCA is seeking information on the incident and is urging the Scottish government to implement air weapon licensing. Last year, the government proposed licensing air weapons, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan, with 87% rejecting it as too strict.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for a significant fee, making him their second most expensive signing. The transfer was triggered by a release clause and is part of Liverpool's efforts to strengthen their attack after a goal-scoring struggle in the previous season. Benteke, a Belgium international, has a strong record with Villa, scoring 49 goals in 101 games. He joins a number of new signings aimed at improving Liverpool's forward line, including Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi. Former managers and players have expressed confidence in Benteke's ability to contribute to Liverpool's success, highlighting his physicality, goal-scoring ability, and potential to help the team win trophies.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence of academic improvement from using tablet devices in schools, despite their widespread adoption. Tablets are now used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% of schools providing individual devices for every pupil. The use of tablets is more prevalent in academy schools than in other types of schools. Although there is no definitive link between tablet use and improved academic results, some head teachers report a positive impact, particularly in motivating disengaged students and increasing family involvement. Tablets are expected to become even more common in schools, with numbers projected to double between 2014 and 2016. A separate study found that touch-screen computers are particularly useful for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. The study also highlights the integration of online technology into the daily lives of young people, with many using devices for social media and entertainment, and a significant number describing themselves as internet "addicts." School leaders emphasize the importance of using technology in education to align with the realities of students' home lives and future work environments.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing the lives of children from the 1880s to the 1990s, illustrating both the changes in childhood and the social history of Liverpool. The images include scenes of children playing and working, with one notable photograph showing the Rollo family from 1887 attending a fancy dress ball. Curator Kay Jones selected the images from the National Museums Liverpool's collections, aiming to highlight both the positive and challenging aspects of childhood experiences. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals, potentially facing his former club on 18 February. Keating, 21, has joined the Gulls, recommended by Micky Adams, and needs international clearance. Nicholson praises Anderson's leadership and notes Keating's hunger despite his inexperience. The Gulls are struggling, sitting four points above the relegation zone with just one win in their last six matches.

Bolivia's new law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, aiming to address the country's poverty by enabling children to supplement family income. The law imposes severe penalties, such as 30 years in jail for child homicide, and was signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales. The legislation seeks to balance Bolivia's needs with international standards, as the International Labour Organisation (ILO) permits 14 as the minimum working age in developing countries. However, the ILO is reviewing the law to determine if it violates international child labor regulations. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia work in various conditions, including dangerous environments like mines and agriculture. Morales's government hopes this law will help reduce extreme poverty.

A 50-year-old woman, O'Donnell, experienced a heart attack after ignoring her symptoms, which included nausea and chest aches. She looked up "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day, who found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. O'Donnell's heart attack was referred to as the "widow maker," and she emphasized the importance of recognizing symptoms and calling emergency services. She is an actress known for shows like Drop Dead Diva and Will and Grace, and recently hosted a talk show that was cancelled due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old boy, Che Labastide-Wellington, was stabbed and later pronounced dead after a fight in an alleyway near a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton. He had been invited to the party, which was described as well-run with appropriate adults present. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and hospitalized in stable condition. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, while two boys aged 15 and 16 were also arrested and bailed until mid-December. A 14-year-old is being held for possession of an offensive weapon. Authorities are seeking witnesses near the alleyway where the stabbing occurred.

The passage discusses a new approach introduced in Denmark to improve cancer diagnosis, particularly for cases that are not initially obvious. The changes were prompted by poor cancer survival rates and long waiting times for diagnosis. The new model includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with alarm symptoms, diagnosis centres for patients with unclear symptoms, and "yes-no" centres for patients with minor symptoms. These changes have improved organisation, reduced waiting times, and led to better survival rates. Wales is looking to learn from Denmark's approach to improve its own cancer diagnosis system.

The passage discusses the UK government's decision to disband the OFT and replace it with Powys, which won a competitive bidding process to deliver the service. Powys will issue warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents and receive £170,000 annually for this work. Complaints about estate agents will still be directed to local trading standards departments, who will refer cases to Powys if they believe the Estate Agents Act has been breached. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, expressed hope that this role could lead to Powys taking on more contracts in the future.

The NHS Employers have approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce, following a Nuffield Trust review that highlighted examples of nurses and other staff filling in for doctors and pharmacists. This comes amid shortages of junior doctors and overwhelmed GPs due to rising patient numbers. The report suggests that with more training, other health staff can help address these issues, especially as care shifts towards managing long-term conditions. However, unions warn against using this as a quick fix and emphasize the need for proper funding and training. While there is support for enhancing the skills of the workforce, concerns remain about not compromising the quality of doctor training and the need for adequate funding for training courses.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing into the collision. First, a bus company, reported that some services had resumed normal schedules, but full service was expected to take a few hours to restore. Managing director James Freeman expressed gratitude for public support and staff efforts in managing the situation.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the Swansea tidal lagoon project. NRW estimated that the lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die annually, while Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, claiming they lack a clear scientific basis and that NRW did not share its methodology. TLP's own modeling suggests a "worst case scenario" of 2% fish mortality. The £1.3bn project is seen as a test for larger tidal lagoon projects along the Welsh coast. The UK government is reviewing the project's viability, and the Welsh Government supports it but seeks clarity on the UK government's stance. NRW maintains confidence in its evidence and methodology, which have been reviewed by independent experts.

The passage discusses the announcement by Northern Ireland's DETI Minister Arlene Foster of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, aimed at enhancing the agri-food industry's strategic leadership and coordination. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and is expected to benefit the sector, which employs nearly 100,000 people. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the move, noting the importance of agri-food for export-led economic growth, but also expressed concerns about potential implications for existing organizations.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting the public to participate in planting 40,000 native UK trees as a tribute to the 40,000 people from Ireland who died in WW1. This is part of a four-year, nationwide project aiming to plant millions of trees to commemorate WW1 casualties. The event is open to local people and visitors, with saplings provided and advice to wear appropriate footwear. The project aims to create a space for wildlife and reflection, with wildflowers like poppies, and is located about seven miles outside Derry city.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book *Someone Else's Skin*, which addresses domestic violence and honour crime. The book is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and was praised for its strong writing and atmosphere. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career writing about detective VI Warshawski, a groundbreaking female protagonist. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers. The awards were presented at the start of Harrogate's annual crime writing festival, with Ann Cleeves, the festival programming chair, highlighting the strength of this year's shortlist.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant setback for the team's qualification hopes. He expressed frustration over the injury but is looking forward to returning in 2017 to make up for lost time. Worcestershire also signed John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man, was killed in 2008 by a speeding car while attempting to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, ruled his death an unlawful killing, citing circumstantial evidence that was deemed overwhelming. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (also known as Anna), was 19 years younger than him and had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove at the time of the incident. Ziuzina tried to claim his assets shortly after his death, leading to suspicions of her involvement in his death for financial gain. The couple met online in 2006 and married in 2007 after a brief engagement. Ziuzina's background was questioned, as she had initially claimed to be a teacher but was later revealed to have been a lap dancer and stripper. The inquest heard that Ziuzina sold Pring's possessions and moved funds from his account. Although the Ukrainian police initially closed the case, it was reopened in 2011 as a murder inquiry, and the case remains active but not actively pursued. Witnesses described the incident as a deliberate act, and the car involved had stolen license plates and did not stop. Ziuzina did not attend the inquest and stated she had already provided statements to Ukrainian police.

Charlie Fearns, a child from Merseyside, requires experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital in the United States, as this treatment is not available in the UK. His mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed gratitude for an anonymous donor who covered the cost of the treatment after the family faced financial and medical challenges. Charlie has been ill since the age of three and has experienced multiple relapses, with the last T-Cell transplant failing. The family received confirmation via email from the hospital that the treatment is now financially cleared, and they expect to start the treatment soon.

Apple has implemented a new two-step verification process to enhance the security of its iCloud service, following reports that third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code sent via text or Apple's Find My iPhone app after logging in from a new device. While this security measure is optional, some experts argue it should be the default setting. The new system also notifies users by email when a backup starts downloading, increasing transparency. However, there are concerns about the recovery key, which is needed to regain access if a trusted device is lost or stolen. If lost, the recovery key could lead to data loss or potential security risks if stolen. Apple plans to encourage users more actively to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, emphasizing the importance of user awareness in security.

Dan Groves mentioned that the finer details of a potential deal, which would see Wright buy 20% of Billericay, are not yet public. The Sun reported that Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant, will become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points away from a play-off spot. Wright has played non-league football for several clubs. The club was recently acquired by Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 weekly, and they signed Paul Konchesky, a former England international, in early March.

Mr Ashley has been requested to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers, following a BBC investigation into the working conditions at his Derbyshire company's warehouse. He has until 21 March to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The committee has offered multiple dates for a meeting but Mr Ashley has not accepted any. The committee warned that if he does not comply, they may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not commented on the matter, but has previously committed to reviewing worker rights under Mr Ashley's oversight, who also owns Newcastle United Football Club.

A report titled "Putin. War" was compiled by Ilya Yashin and colleagues following the assassination of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov. It compiles existing information from media about Russia's involvement in eastern Ukraine since 2014, arguing that President Putin is waging war for his own benefit. The report claims that Russian troops and equipment were crucial to separatist victories, with soldiers admitting they were directed to Ukraine for combat operations. It highlights the financial cost of the conflict and the lack of compensation for families of Russian soldiers killed in the war. Despite the report's findings, distributing such material is difficult in Russia, and the opposition's efforts may face the same fate as Nemtsov's previous works, which failed to spark significant public protests against Putin.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead in the Woodhead Tunnels near A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. He suffered head injuries, which caused his death. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses tensions between the Welsh government and the UK government regarding Brexit negotiations. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, criticized the UK government for not consulting Wales on the Article 50 letter, feeling it was disrespectful. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's actions, emphasizing the need to act in the UK's best interest. Prime Minister Theresa May mentioned Wales in the letter, stating that powers would be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, though specifics remain unclear. Concerns about funding accompanying these powers were raised, with Carwyn Jones fearing a lack of financial support post-2020. The passage highlights the uncertainty around which powers will be devolved and whether funding will follow.

On Friday night, two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay at the attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were attacked while carrying out their duties and urged parents to keep track of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The board stated in a San Francisco court filing that they do not expect him to return to the firm. Mr. Charney's lawyer claimed many of the statements made by the company were false, alleging an invasion of privacy and an attempt to extort him. The court documents include evidence of illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory remarks by Mr. Charney. The company's filing states that Mr. Charney repeatedly violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board argues that it would be difficult for any company to hire Mr. Charney due to the significant risk involved. Recently, American Apparel obtained a restraining order to prevent Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between Great Britain and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The previous match in Patras, Greece, saw Greece win 92-64, but three key players from that team will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor is excited about playing at the Copper Box in London, emphasizing the importance of the game for preparing for EuroBasket 2017. This will be Britain's only home game before their EuroBasket qualifiers in Istanbul, followed by a tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before the competition. The game will take place from 17:30 to 19:30 BST.

The passage recounts the author's experience covering the launch of the iPhone, highlighting the initial skepticism and the eventual recognition of its transformative impact. It describes how the iPhone revolutionized technology by integrating powerful computing into a handheld device, changing industries and daily life. The author reflects on the iPhone's role in advancing photography and mobility, contrasting early phone cameras with the capabilities of modern smartphones. While initially critical of the hype, the author now acknowledges the iPhone's historical significance, marking the beginning of the mobile connected era.

A series of cat poisonings have occurred near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, with tests confirming the cats ingested a toxic substance, likely antifreeze. Seven-month-old Meereen died after being found foaming at the mouth and trying to vomit, with her owner devastated by the loss. This is the fourth cat to die in the area in the past two weeks. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially as antifreeze use increases during this time of year.

The passage discusses Greece's current economic situation under the Syriza government, which is set to implement more austerity measures despite previously opposing them. Despite this, there are no street demonstrations in Athens, and Greek resorts are busy with tourists. The author questions why Greeks are not protesting against new austerity measures, suggesting that the calm may be before the announcement of significant concessions made by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to secure a new bailout. The passage highlights Greece's economic struggles, including a lack of credit and the impact on businesses, and suggests that for the new bailout to be successful, creditors should consider debt forgiveness to help Greece recover.

Ross Kemp will return to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes, marking his first appearance since 2006. Barbara, who had left in 2010, returned to Albert Square to inform her son Phil that her cancer had returned, and it was revealed that Peggy would die from the disease in upcoming episodes. Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell to bring the Mitchell family back together for Barbara's final moments. Grant Mitchell, a legendary character in EastEnders, is set to reunite with his brother Phil and face the loss of their mother, providing emotional and classic episodes.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and murdered Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were informed of her death by police and immediately suspected Dhillon. Sue had previously reassured Alice that the police were handling the situation, but her daughter Emma warned her that Dhillon might kill Alice. Sue later felt guilty for dismissing Emma's concerns. Despite signs of the severity of the situation, Alice's parents and even Alice herself did not fully realize how serious it was. In memory of Alice, her parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and received a minimum 22-year sentence.

EDF, a French firm, has approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant in Somerset, with Chinese investors contributing one third of the cost. However, the UK government, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, has expressed caution and initiated a further review of the project, causing uncertainty. Critics have raised concerns about environmental impact, potential cost overruns, and the involvement of foreign governments, particularly China. EDF's financial capacity has also been questioned, with recent resignations of key executives and the need for additional funding. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity and is seen as crucial for energy supply and climate commitments. Environmental groups argue that the project is not cost-effective and advocate for investment in renewable energy. The Hinkley Point project has faced numerous delays and uncertainties since its proposal in 2006.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person with whom the spouse committed adultery, which has raised concerns among family lawyers. They argue that involving a third party increases conflict and complexity. Although there is no obligation to name the person, the presence of the question may encourage people to fill it in. The form aims to be more user-friendly, especially for those without legal advice. However, naming the third party can lead to delays and additional costs if they do not respond. Adultery was a reason for 12,148 divorces in 2015, while "unreasonable behaviour" was cited in 46,815 cases. Lawyers warn that involving the third party can negatively impact the petitioner's case and that judges are unlikely to favor such actions.
